sp.p: Not a Scholar goes from thence to England, but the whole Colledge rings of it.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: And then, my Lord, when they go out they go in Secular Cloaths, that none but muſt know when any perſon leaves the Colledge,

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, in ſuch caſes, though tis true in a general ſenſe, yet it is but a general Rule, and every general Rule admits of its exceptions, and my caſe was a particular Exception. I put on the habit of the Houſe as ſoon as I did return from London, and did not appear as if I had gone out of the Houſe, nor did I know that it was known that I had been out; for I did never appear in a ſecular habit.

sp.speaker: Whitebread,
sp.p: What his Cloaths were, does not change the place he ſate in; he being ancienter than the Boys, had a priviledge to ſit in a particular place, which muſt be known to all the Houſe at Dinner and Supper. He was viſible every day there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I do believe it; and therefore he ſays, not only that he was reported to be there, but that he ſaw him there almoſt every day.

p.hi: Then another Witneſs for the Priſoner ſtood up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you, young Lad?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: I ſay, my Lord—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Dr Oates,
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, ask him if he went by that Name at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton.
sp.p: What was your Name at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Doddington
sp.p: My name was Hollis there.

sp.speaker: L. C, J.
sp.p: How old are you?

sp.speaker: Doddington
sp.p: Eighteen years and an half.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ſay? where was m • , Oates?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: He never went out of the Colledge, but one night to Watton, till the end of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came he into the Colledge?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: A fortnight before Chriſtmas, I did not mind the day, he ſays himſe •• it was the 10th of December.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt
sp.p: Was he there till June?

sp.speaker: Doddington.
sp.p: Yes, he never went out till June but one night.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where was that? At Watton?

sp.speaker: Doddington.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Doddington.
sp.p: I only know that by what all the houſe ſaid.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him every day, except that day?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: I cannot ſay I ſaw him every day, becauſe he was in the Infirmary once, and he was there that very day after Mr. Hilſly went away.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What day was it that Mr. Hilſly went away?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: The 24th of April new ſtile; and that day he fell ſick, and went into the Infirmary the next.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What day of the week was that?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: It was of a Sunday.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: And when did you ſee Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: On monday or Tueſday, I am not certain.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How often did you ſee him from the 24th of April to June? Did you ſee him every other day?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: Yes, that I am ſure of, for every other day, I am not certain every day.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Are you poſitive?

sp.speaker: Jury,
sp.p: We deſire to know what time of the year he was in the Infirmary.

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: I diſcourſed with him in the Infirmary two or three days after Mr. Hilſly went away.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: But what time of the year was it?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: He was there firſt in Winter, and then afterwards he was in at this time, which was in April.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Have you any more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Doddington.
sp.p: I can ſay more, that I ſaw Mr. Oates the ſecond of May with one Blood or Burnaby, and I am ſure I ſaw him in his company.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: I ſaw him walking in the Garden with Mr. Burnaby.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt, Pemberton,
sp.p: When did you come into England?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: I came over the 24th of April.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How long have you been in England?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: About two months,

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p:
Why did you come over, were you ſent for over upon this oc
• aſion?

sp.speaker: Doddington,
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Why did you come over?

sp.speaker: Doddington.
sp.p: I came over partly upon the Kings Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What Proclamation was that?

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt. North,
sp.p: That thoſe that were in the Seminaries ſhould come over again.

sp.speaker: Doddington.
sp.p: And partly becauſe I had not my health.

sp.speaker: Fenwick,
sp.p: Mr. Gifford, what do you know about Mr. Oates's coming from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came you from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: I came over about a month ago.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Upon what occaſion?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: To Juſtifie that Mr. Oats was there all the while that he ſays he was here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſpeak like an honeſt man, there is no hurt in that.

sp.speaker: Fenwick,
sp.p: we did ſend for him over.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oates there?

sp.speaker: Gifford.
sp.p: I ſaw him the firſt of May was twelve-month with us, and the 21. of April.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And how long after that?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: I was in his Company for a whole week after, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſay the firſt of May he was there, how can you tell?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: The firſt of May there came one Mr. Burnaby to the Colledg, and he fell into acquaintance with him, and I ſaw him with him. He was with us an whole week at leaſt every day after dinner. We have an hour always after dinner to recreate in, and this Gentleman was there with us and Mr. Burnaby; for Mr. Oates ſeeing us in the Garden at firſt, put himſelf into our company, and kept with us.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he not in the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: Not at that time, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was he in the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: The day after Hilſly went away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember that?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: L.C. Juſt. North.
sp.p: How long did he ſtay in the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: Parry,
sp.p: About three days.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: And for how long together did you ſee him after Mr. Hilſly's departure?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: I can ſwear that I ſaw him at leaſt till June, if I can believe my own eyes.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Your Religion does not allow you to believe your own eyes.

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: I can in my conſcience ſay, I believe I did ſee him every day or every other day.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Which do you ſay, Did you ſee him every other day, or every day?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: If I ſay I ſaw him every other day; that is ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know that he went out of the Colledge at any time?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: Yes, he went for one night.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: To a place called Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: What did he go thither for?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: For his Relaxation.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How came you to take ſuch particular notice of him that he was there?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: It is impoſſible but we ſhould ſee him, and take notice of him, for we dine all together in one Room, and we could not but take notice of him, for he was at a diſtinct Table by himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How many are there that dine in one Room?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: One hundred and fifty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How could you know him when there were ſo many?

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: He was at a diſtinct Table by himſelf, between the Boys and the Religious.

div.p: Then ſtood up another, one Palmer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Fenwick.
sp.p: The ſame Queſtion as the reſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came you from St Omers?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: I came two or three months ago.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice,
sp.p: Why did you come over?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: I had no mind to ſtay any Longer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where does your Father live?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: By Windſor.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Maſter Oates?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: I ſaw him the firſt day of May new ſtile, and I know it for a particular reaſon there were ſtrangers dined at the Colledge that day, whereupon Mr. Oates, and ſeveral other Boys played at Nine pins, in the Afternoon I ſaw them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, you do not count a • l Boys there, do you?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: All but thoſe that are the Religious.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, you did not count Mr. Oates a Boy, did you?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: He was none of the Religious: He ſate indeed at a Table by himſelf, but he went to School with the Boys, and we called all the Scholars Boys.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How often did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: I'le tell your Lordſhip, I ſaw him the firſt of May, for that reaſon; the ſecond of May I ſaw him with Maſter Burnaby, a man that he had never ſeen in all his life before, and we wondred that he had ſo much impudence to inſinuate himſelf into his company.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: He is a Gentleman that is now in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How do you know that Maſter Oates had no acquaintance with him before?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: Becauſe I know he was in England, and came over while Maſter Oates was actually at St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: But he might be of his Acquaintance in England.

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: I heard Maſter Burnaby ſay, he never ſaw Maſter Oates in all his life before. The ſecond of May I ſaw him at the Action, the fifth of May Maſter Killingbeck went away, and I ſaw Maſter Oates actually there then, and one Maſter Poole went away, and I remember Oates was there for a particular reaſon; he was a kind of a weak man, ſomething ſoft, not over-wiſe, and we were asking him why he would go away by himſelf, and talking of it afterwards, ſayes Maſter Oates, I will not ſay poſitively thoſe were the words, but that was the ſence, He does not go alone, for there goes Eſquire Poole and Eſquire Fool together. The eleventh day we had an Action, a Play alſo whereupon there was a particular place for the Muſicians to play in, where no one elſe was to ſit; Maſter Oates would ſit there, and thereupon there was one Maſter Watſon quarrell'd with him, and they had like to have fought.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: This was the 11th of May?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, new ſtile, and the other was the 5th.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you ſaw him betwixt that time?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: And ſo for how long?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: I ſaw him at four a clock in a morning reading Father Worſleys Controverſies, and ſo for ſeveral days together.

sp.speaker: Fenwick,
sp.p: Did he go away before June?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: No, he did never ſtir till June.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: Did not you go ſometime by the name of Sanders or H • ll?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: No, only by the name of Thomas Palmer.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins,
sp.p: Heark you Sir, who maintained you at St, Omers? Do not you know one Mr. Caryl?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: No my Fa • her maintained me.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Who is your Father?

sp.speaker: Palmer,
sp.p: Sir Philip Palmer.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Country Gentleman is he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: He is Cup bearer to the King.

div.p: Then ſtood up one Maſter Cox.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you been from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: Two months.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Country man are you?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: I was born at Bruſſels to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know Maſter Oates?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: Yes, I did very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: At Saint Omers.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: I left St. Omers ſeven months ago, and I came away in the month of November after Maſter Oates. My Lord, I can prove that he was there in April and May. I went from St. Omers to Bruſſels, and from Bruſſels I came ſtraight to London.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: But when did you ſee Maſter Oate there?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I can prove I ſaw him at St. Omers when he ſays he was in England, and that by this circumſtance. Maſter Pool who was my Muſick Maſter was ſick there, and Mr. Oates was often with him.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice,
sp.p: Were you there all the time he was there?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: Yes, I was, till he went away.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When did he go away?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: Maſter Oates went away in the month of July.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Not in June?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: No, my Lord, July.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Why he differs from all the reſt?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: My Lord, I can prove he was at St. Omers when he ſays he was in England.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief J.
sp.p: Why what month did he go away?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: My Lord, I can prove that Mr. Oates was never abſent from St. Omers, till he went away for good and all.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: He went after the Conſult of the Jeſuits, which he ſays was in England in April.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Come, come, Anſwer me plainly if you can in what month Mr. Oates left St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: I ſay Mr. Oates was never abſent from St. Omers till the Conſult of the Jeſuit, was over, which he hath confeſſed himſelf to be at.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: Why it was after May, 'tis no matter what the month was whether June or July. (at which the people laughed.)

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: What do you laught at Sirs? Why, ſuppoſe I miſtake the month it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief J.
sp.p: Look you we are now upon a Queſtion of time, and you cannot tell that a man i • there at a certain time, unleſs you can prove the certain time when he came away?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: I can prove that he was there till after the Conſult of the Jeſuits, (and then the people laughed again)

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p:
Ay, I • elieve you there, 'tis enough for you, but you have done a very great prejudice to thoſe perſons that you came for, for you come to prove the concluſion,
but do not take notice of what Mediums you are to uſe. Say you, if I can but prove that he was there till after the conſult of the Jeſuits, that is the thing in Queſtion, and I need no more, but this is ſerving a turn only: Pray can you tell me what month he came to St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: Yes, he came thither in the month of December.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And when did he go away again?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: He was never abſent from St. Omers out of the view of the Scholars, except one night that he went to Watton, and one day when he was in the Infirmary, but even at that time he was ſeen by ſome of the Scholars.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yet you cannot tell the time that he went away?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: He was never abſent all the while.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Windham.
sp.p: Do you know when the Conſult of the Jeſuites was? upon what day?

sp.speaker: Cox,
sp.p: He ſayes he went away with Mr. Hilſley, but he did not, I can prove the contrary.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, he ſays he followed him and overtook him at Calis.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: That is falſe, and I can prove it by this Circumſtance: one Mr. Conqueſt was to go for England that day, and he came into the Refectory, and told us a ſtory of this Mr. Conqueſts being unwilling to riſe in the morning to go for England.

sp.speaker: L, C. J.
sp.p: When did he tell that ſtory?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: That day that he was to go for England,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long was that after Mr. Hilſley went away?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: The day after.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: When was the time that Mr. Conqueſt went for England?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: In the month of May as we count.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time in the month of May?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: It was the fifth: and he ſays that Mr. Pool and Mr. Nevill were in England with him, but I can teſtifie that they were not abſent, for one of them was my muſick-maſter.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Was he there all May?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Yes, that I can teſtifie upon my Oath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And all June?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, but if I prove he was not in May in England it is ſufficient.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon my word you deſerve a ſharp penance for running into that fault 2 or 3 times: you have done them no kindneſs in this matter.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip will take advantage of every Circumſtance, young men may not remember the particular day of his going away.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you hear how he delivers his Evidence, 'tis as if he had been inſtructed, you muſt come and prove that Oates was not in England in April and May, and that will do our buſineſs, for he tells you it is ſufficient, but we will have it proved to ſatisfie us.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: But why ſhould I ſay more than I know?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You mean, more than you are inſtructed about. I only ask you one ſhort queſtion, Do you know when Mr. Oates left St Omers? Name the moneth.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: If you don't remember the time, ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot Remember it.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: Then call another. (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire they may be Examined apart.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You need not trouble your ſelf about that. What is your name?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: My name is Thomas Billing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came you from S. Omers?

sp.speaker: Billing
sp.p: I came 3 moneths ago I think my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Billing,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee him at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Billing,
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw him when he came the ſame day, or the day after.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Billing,
sp.p: In December my Lord, the 10th. of December.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And he ſtaid there how long?

sp.speaker: Billing,
sp.p: Till the Latter end of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: was he never abſent?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: I can very well remember that he went to Watton in the Chriſtmas. I was then in he Infirmary my ſelf, and he and his Companion came in there to ſee us, and ſaid he had been at Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But he was twice in the Infirmary, was he not?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was the ſecond time?

sp.speaker: Billing,
sp.p: The ſecond time was in April, I went in the week before Chriſtmas, on St. Thomas of Canterbury's day I came out again.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But you ſay the ſecond time was in April?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long was he there then?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: Truly I was not with him then, but I think 3 or 4 days.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Were you in the Colledge then?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: Yes my Lord I was.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him in the Colledge from time to time?

sp.speaker: Billing
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: For all the time that he ſtaid.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long was that?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: That was from December till the latter end of June.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was he there all May?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord. He ſays he was 8 days in England, but he could not be ſo, for he entred himſelf into the Sodality the 25th of March, and not long after his admiſſion, he was put to read every Sunday morning at 6 a Clock. And after that he began once to read he never was abſent from that time, till the time he went away.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why did he read when he was ſick?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: He was not ſick upon the Sunday.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You ſay he was ſick in April?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But was he not ſick of a Sunday in April?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: He was only a little indiſpoſed, and frequented the infirmary in the day time for a matter of 3 or 4 dayes.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did he read at the time he was ſick in the infirmary?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: He was not ſick an whole week.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch Juſt.
sp.p: Did it reach to a Sunday?

sp.speaker: Billing,
sp.p: No, my Lord that I remember.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: How long did he continue there?

sp.speaker: Billing
sp.p: Til towards the latter end of June.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him once in 2 or 3 days?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p:
Yes my Lord I did conſtantly. And upon the ſecond of May,
•• ve • particularly remember, looking out into the Garden, I ſaw Mr. Blunt walking in the Garden, and Mr. Oates with him: And obſerving him to be very intimately familiar with him, I a • ked ſome that were with me, Does, this Sampſon, for he went by that name
in the Colledge, ſays I, does Sampſon know Dick Blunt? no ſaid they, and we wondered at his confidence having no greater acquaintance, I ſaw him that day walking in the Garden with that Blunt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That was the ſecond of May?

sp.speaker: Billing,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J,
sp.p: And he was conſtantly in this Gentlemans company that day?

sp.speaker: Billing.
sp.p: Yes, and moreover the ſame day this Sampſon ▪ was walking with one John Ruſhton in the Garden, and ſeeing me walk alone, Thomas, ſays he have you never a companion? No Sampſon ſaid I, well ſaid he prithe come to us. So I was with him walking a little while, and then this Blunt and one Henry Howard were playing one with another, throwing ſtones at one anothers Shins. At which he was diſpleaſed, and ſaid • f they would not be quiet he would go tell the Rector. Howard was haſty and ſpoke angerly to him, and ſaid if he would not be quiet he would beat him: But Mr. Oates perſiſting, and daring of him, ſays h • , what do you dare me? and come up to him and throws up Mr. Oates his heels, With that mr. Oates lookt very fre • fully upon him and withdrew himſelf into the Infirmary, as we thought to ſpeak to the Rector. And by theſe particulars, and ſuch as theſe I remember to have ſeen him every day, one day with another, or every other day at St. Omers till he went away which was in June.

div.p: Then ſtood up another, one Townely.

sp.speaker: L, C. J.
sp.p: Come mr. Townely, do you know mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord:

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came you from St Omers?

sp.speaker: Townely
sp.p: I came a week before Eaſter.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When ſaw you this ſame Mr. Oates at St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: I ſaw him in June.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When elſe?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: In May.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When elſe?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: In April.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was he there in all April, all May, and all June?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: No, not all June. He went away as I take it about the 10th of June?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Pray how often did you ſee him? Did you ſee him every day?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: I converſed with him every day. He was partly a Scholar and partly a Father: and ſat at a Table by himſelf. He went to School as a Scholar; 'Tis true indeed, he did not learn as the reſt of the Boys did, but he went to School at the Boys did, and was at a Table from the Fathers as the Boys were, but apart and alone.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But how often did you ſee him? was it every other day?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: Yes, I believe I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What for all April and all May?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How came you to take ſuch particular notice of it that you can ſay, you ſaw him every other day?

If I conſtantly dine with one, or if he be at a ſingle Table alone, he cannot be abſent, but I muſt take notice of it: and he was neither as a Father nor as a Scholar but betwixt both, and therefore the more to be taken notice of.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch Juſt.
sp.p: This then you ſay, He ſiting by himſelf and being diſtinct from all • he others, you might more eaſily obſerve his abſence than any others. This is that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You ſay well. Call another.

div.p: Then ſtood up one Fall.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When came you from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: about Two months agoe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oates?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I ſaw him when I was in my Syntax, and now I am in Poetry.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What moneth did you ſee him in?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: When he came firſt as I rember it was at Chriſtmas.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Chriſtmas laſt?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: No, it was Chriſtmas was twelth month, Chriſtmas 1677.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long did you ſee him there?

sp.speaker: Fall,
sp.p: I ſaw him there from that time till June, only when he was at Watton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J,
sp.p: Was he never ſick?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I ſaw him in the Infirmary my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can you tell when a man is ſick?

sp.speaker: Fall,
sp.p: I do not pretend to do that, but he was in the Infirmary as a ſick man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to take particular notice of it?

sp.speaker: Fall,
sp.p: I took no particular notice, but I have recollected my memory.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon what occaſion?

sp.speaker: Fall,
sp.p: Upon this occaſion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Fall,
sp.p: I ſaw him every day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you been in the Convent?

sp.speaker: Fall,
sp.p: My Lord I have been there two years and an half. (Then ſtood up John Hall.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: When came you from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: in July my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: How long have you been there?

sp.speaker: Hall
sp.p: ſeven years and upwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long is it ſince you came from thence?

sp.speaker: Hall
sp.p: In July in the year 1678.

sp.speaker: L, C. J.
sp.p: And did you ſee M • . Oates there then?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: No, my Lord,

sp.speaker: L.C.J,
sp.p: When did you ſee him there then.

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: I ſaw him there in April, May, & June

sp.speaker: L. C.J.
sp.p: What all June?

sp.speaker: Hall
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long in June?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: He went away about the Twenty third of June.

sp.speaker: L. C, J.
sp.p: How came you to take ſuch particular notice Mr. Oates was there all this while?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: I was a ſervant there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: A Reſectorian, a Butler.

sp.speaker: L. C. J,
sp.p: Did you keep Books of what meat and drink they had?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: No, I laid their Table, drew their Beer and laid the Bread.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And did you ſerve Mr. Oates with bread and Beer every day?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: Yes my Lord, moſt Dayes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſerve the Infirmary?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you ſay you ſerved him every day?

sp.speaker: Hall.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, the moſt of the time he remained there, I acknowledge he was in the Infirmary.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long?

sp.speaker: Hall.
sp.p: Four or five days, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he in the Colledge in April?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: Yes my Lord, all along.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And all May?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I ſaw him all May, I laid his Table neer the door at a particular place where he always ſate.

sp.speaker: Jury,
sp.p: My Lord, we deſire to know what employment he is of now?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hall, what made you come into England?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: My Lord, I had not my health there.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: How long had you lived there?

sp.speaker: Hall
sp.p: Seven years and upwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: And when began you to be ſick?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: I had not my health at Chriſtmas in December, 1677.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What employment have you here, for you had a good place there?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: I live at home with my Father and my friends.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is your Father? where lives h • ?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: He is a Gentleman, he lives in Radnorſhire.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came you to London?

sp.speaker: Hall
sp.p: I came to England in July, 1678.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you ſay you Father is in Radnorſhire, when came you here to Lnndon?

sp.speaker: Hall,
sp.p: I have been here about a moneth, I was ſummoned up as a Witneſs.

div.p: Then one Dalliſon, was called who did not appear, and one Manſhall appearing, but ſpeaking French and no Engliſh, and an Interpreter not being ready, he was for the preſent by the conſent of the Priſoners ſet aſide. And then ſtood up one Cook.

sp.speaker: L. C J.
sp.p: When came you from St. Omers?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: In January Laſt

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And where have you been ever ſince?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: Here in Town my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does your Father live here in Town?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do your friends live here?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You came over upon this occaſion did you?
Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee Mr. Oates there?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: I ſaw him in laſt June,

sp.speaker: L: C J:
sp.p: And was he there in July?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: No, my Lord,

sp.speaker: L: C: J:
sp.p: What time did he go away?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: The 23d, the Eve of the Feaſt of St: Iohn Baptiſt.

sp.speaker: L: C: J:
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: I made him ſome Clothes:

sp.speaker: L: C: J:
sp.p: Are you a Taylor?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: Yes:

sp.speaker: L: C: J:
sp.p: How often did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: Every day:

sp.speaker: L: C: J.
sp.p: How came he to keep you company?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: I could not chuſe but ſee him, ſometimes I ſaw him 20 times a day.

sp.speaker: L. C: J.
sp.p: Where was he in April?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: He was there all April.

sp.speaker: L.C. J.
sp.p: He might be abſent one day or ſo, and you ſee him not,

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: He uſed to come twice a week to my ſhop for things.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there all May?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſay you ſaw him every other day?

sp.speaker: Cooke
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr. Levins
sp.p: Why Sir there are 150 Scholars there, how can you tell he was there ſo well?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Pemberton:
sp.p: Can you tell every one that was there all that time?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: No, I can't tell every one that was there, but he was particular enough.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you live in Town as a Taylor or in the Colledge?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: In the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood,
sp.p: Was Mr. Oates at Watton any part of the time?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Belwood,
sp.p: What day? what month?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: I cannot juſtly ſay the day, but it was in April,
How long was he abſent?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: Only one night as it ſhall pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Heark you, how came you to take notice that he was at Watton one night?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: It was talked of among all the Scholars.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How can you remember what was ſaid a year ago of one man?

sp.speaker: Cooke,
sp.p: It was reported all over the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: In one place of his Narrative, he ſays, he came over with Sir John Warner, and Sir Thomas Preſton.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: That is nothing to the purpoſe. If you can contradict him in any thing that hath been ſworn here, do.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: If we can prove him a perjured man at any time we do our buſineſs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſhould have proved him a perjur'd man before. How can we prove one Cauſe in another? and then too he had been provided to make his defence, Can he come prepared to make good every thing that he hath ſaid in his life?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Can I come to make good my Evidence againſt all I have done in my life?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Look you, if ſo be he hath forſworn himſelf in any former Tryal, if that would appear you have all the reaſon to make uſe of it, but you have not taken the right way, you ſhould have indicted him and tryed him for perjury in the former Trial, and then he could not have been heard at all in this.

sp.speaker: Whitebread,
sp.p: We were all Priſoners cloſe ſhut up.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice,
sp.p: We know you have a party ſtrong enough, and willing enough to convict him of Perjury if they could; but look you Gentlemen here is the thing, if you can give ſuch Evidence as will ſatisfie the Jury that he was abſent all April and all May you have ſaid a great thing. His Evidence will be quite contradicted.

sp.speaker: Whitebread,
sp.p: He ſays he came over with Sir Thomas Preſton and Sir John Warner and others.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: He ſays nothing of it now.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: May it pleaſe you my Lord, I will anſwer it if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: They deſire to know who came over with you when you came over in April.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I will tell you, and to convince the Court, that in neither of the Trials I did contradict my ſelf, I ſay, I did name ſome perſons at one time that I did not name at another. There came over with me the Rector of Liege, Sir John Warner, Father Williams, Father Mariſh, Father Warner, Sir Tho. Preſton and others.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: This is dea • ing plainly with you.

div.p: Then ſtood up one Bartlett.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What Countrey-man are you?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: I am a Dutch man.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Can you ſpeak Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: Yes a little.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When came you from Saint Omers?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: I came from Saint Omers the 23 of May in the year 1678. new ſtile.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: My Lord, this man is come over to teſtifie, that Oates is perjured in a circumſtance about Sir John Warner.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: He is to contradict Mr. Oates teſtimony, for he ſays he came over with Sir John Warner, and you ſay Sir John did not come at that time.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Well when did Sir John Warner come over from Saint Omers?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Into England:

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: Sir John Warner ▪ hath not been in England all May, and all the month of April.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: He was at Watton, I did ſee him there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you there all that time?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt. North,
sp.p: Were you there all May?

sp.speaker: Bartlet,
sp.p: Yes, I was:

sp.speaker: L, C, J.
sp.p: When did you come over into England laſt?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: The 23th of May

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long have you been in England?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: About 5 or 6 weeks.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: My Name is Bartlett.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: But you ſay that you came over the 23th of May.

sp.speaker: Bartlett;
sp.p: I did not come over till the latter end of June.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Juſt now you ſaid, you came over the 23th of May.

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: No, my Lord, I thought you had asked the queſtion when Mr. Oates came over.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: He ſays ſo, as your Lordſhip ſays before.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How do you know when Mr. Oates came over?

sp.speaker: Bartlett,
sp.p: I heard ſo beyond Sea.

div.p: Then one Carlier a Foreigner appearing, and not being able to ſpeak Engliſh, Mr. Tiſſer the Under-ſheriff of Middleſex was ſworn truly to interpret his Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr Tiſſer, you are only to tell us what he ſays. Ask him when he came into England laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: He ſays, my Lord, it was between ſeven and eight weeks ago.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Ask him, if he knows where Sir John Warner was laſt Summer was a year ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: He ſays, my Lord, he was in Watton for two years laſt paſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: Ask him where he was all April was twelvemonth, and all May:

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: My Lord, he ſays, that the laſt Sunday in April, Sir John Warner was at his houſe at Watton.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: And where was he all May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: In the ſame houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Ask him how he does know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: My Lord, he ſaith, that he was a Gardener there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It ſeems he ſays to the ſame effect as the laſt Witneſs did. Call another.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: What is this mans name?

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: His name is Charles Verron.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Does he ſpeak any Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: No, he does not.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Tiſſer, ask him if he knows Sir John Warner, and where he was April and May was twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Lr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: He ſays, my Lord, that he was at Watton all April and May, and continued there till September.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray ask this man what quality he is of there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer.
sp.p: He goes along with a Veſſel between Saint Omers and Watton, and that he knows it to be true.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief. J.
sp.p: Ask him, if he did ſee him every day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: He ſays, generally, my Lord, dayly.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Ask him what Religion he is of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: He ſays he is of the Roman Religion.

div.p: Then ſtood up one Baillee.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Ask him, Mr. Tiſſer, if he knows Sir John Warner; and where he was all April and May was twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: He ſays the ſame, that he was at Watton all April and May.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Ask him how he can tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: He ſays he is a Servant of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: And did he ſee him there dayly?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſſer,
sp.p: My Lord, he ſays that he gave him directions to make a Baſtyment, that he is a Maſon, and that he did give him directions dayly about it, and that he ſaw him every day.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt,
sp.p: Look you, Gentlemen of the Jury, he ſpeaks to the ſame purpoſe that the three Witneſſes before ſpoke to; he ſays he is a Maſon, and that he built a Baſtyment there by direction from Sir John Warner, and that Sir John Warner came dayly to give directions about it.

div.p: Then ſtood up John Joſeph.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know Sir Thomas Preſton?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: In the months of April, May and June:

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he then?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: He was at the Engliſh Houſe at Liege.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him there? how often did you ſee him there?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: I ſaw him there every day almoſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What occaſion had you to ſee him? what were you there?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: I was Porter of the Gate.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: And did you ſee him all the month of April?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: Every day, moſt commonly.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee him once in a day or two?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: I did ſee him in April, May and June.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: That you might do; but did you ſee him very day?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: Every day moſt commonly, I cannot abſolutely ſay, but two or three days in a week.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins,
sp.p: Pray do you know of any time that Sir Tho. Preſton was abſent from Leige.

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: He was in the time of the vacancy.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins,
sp.p: Was he not abſent in April or May?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: When are the vacancies?

sp.speaker: Joſeph,
sp.p: In Auguſt, my Lord.

div.p: Then ſtood up one Peter Carpenteer.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know Sir Th • . Preſton?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt,
sp.p: Where did you know him?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: I knew him at Leige.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How often did you ſee him there in April and May.

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: Every day I ſaw him there all April and May.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What Office had you there?

sp.speaker: Carpenteer,
sp.p: I was Caterer.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: My Lord, we have no more Witneſſes as to this point. But, my Lord, my Caſe is different from the others: Mr. Oates ſays he did not ſee me in the Congregation, but he ſays, he afterwards ſaw my hand to the Conſult. Now, my Lord, I have a Witneſs to prove that I was at that time at Wolverhampton in Staffordſhire. No body hath a right to ſit in the Congregation till he become a profeſſed Jeſuit, which at that time I was not.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: He does not charge you to have been there, though he ſays he ſaw your hand to it.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: My Lord, I was then in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: That will do you ſome, and yet but little ſervice, if you can prove your ſelf at Wolverhampton at that time: but call your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Gaven, he ſays, he ſaw a Letter of yours giving an account how affairs ſtood in Staffordſhire and Shropſhire, and that afterwards in July, and before that Gentleman Mr. Aſhby went to the Bath, he heard you diſcourſe of the ſame matter: And though he cannot charge his memory to ſay he ſaw you the 24th of April, yet, ſays he, I did ſee his hand to the Conſult; and being asked how he knew your hand, he ſays he knew it by your writing a Bill of Exchange in his preſence.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: I could not ſign the Conſult at London, and not be at London.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief J. North.
sp.p: I believe in ſuch a buſineſs you care not how many hands you have; but we will not prevent you calling your Witneſſes. You are upon your life, don't ſpend the time, call them quickly.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What do you call them to prove?

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: To prove that I was at Wolverhampton the 24th and 25th of April.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt,
sp.p: Pray hear what he ſays himſelf. You ſay, Sir, you ſaw his hand to the Conſult that was in April; pray when was it that you ſaw it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It was in June or July.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North.
sp.p: You might ſet your hand afterwards to it, if you were not there then.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: You ſay you were then in Staffordſhire, and might not you ſet your hand afterwards when you came to Town? I will tell you, Mr. Gaven, in April they met, and had ſuch a Reſolution; you were then in Staffordſhire, might not you come to Town in July following, and ſet your hand to what was agreed in April before? And you cannot contradict him, but by ſhewing that all June and July you were not here: For if you prove your ſelf never ſo much to have been at Wolverhampton in April, that will not ſerve the turn. You ſeem to make a very great defence of this: All that Mr. Oates ſays, is, that the 24th of April he was preſent where there was a Conſult had about the death of the King, and divers perſons ſet their hands to the Reſolve. Mr. Gaven afterwards was in Town, and then, ſays he I ſaw his hand ſet to the Conſult: I will not charge my memory to ſay he was preſent but I will tell you why I believe it was his Hand, becauſe I ſaw him draw a Bill of Exchange, and that was juſt like the ſame Hand.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: Aye but, my Lord, I was not here in April.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: But this proves, in effect, that you ſet your hand to the thing afterwards. And now if you ſhould prove your ſelf never ſo plainly not to have been there in April, you do not come to the thing: it is ſtill a non liquet whether you were here in July or no. And Mr. Oates does not poſitively charge you as to April. Well, call your Witneſſes, and prove what you will.

div.p: Catherine Winford was called, and appeared.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: I deſire you would be pleaſed to ask her, where I was the 23th of July.

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: My Lord, I am very ſure he was a Sojourner at our Houſe the moſt part of the Summer, in June and July both: In July the 23th he went away from my Houſe, and took another Lodging more convenient for that which he had to do.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where? in what Town was this?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: At Wolverhampton in Staffordſhire.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: was he never away from you all that time?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: No, and then he went to another Lodging in the Town.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you ſay that he ſojourned with you all June & July till the 23th?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: He ſojourned with me longer; but I only name thoſe months, becauſe they are onely in queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did he go when he went from you?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: He took another lodging in the Town.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And did you ſee him then?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: I ſaw him then every day, or every other day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you a Roman Catholick?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am ſo.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call another.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: Call Mary Poole. (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Gaven?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C, J.
sp.p: How long have you know him?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: This ſix or ſeven years.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray do you know where he was this time Twelvemonth?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: He was at Mrs. Winfords Houſe at Wolverhampton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J,
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Poole,
sp.p: I was a Servant there in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: And where was he in April?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: He was at my Miſtreſſes Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And where was he in May?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: my Lord, I believe he was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And why do you believe he was there?

sp.speaker: Poole,
sp.p: Becauſe I do not remember his going forth, till the latter end of July, and he was there in June too.

sp.speaker: L. C, J.
sp.p: You anſwer readily as to June and July, why did you ſtick at the month of May, more than the other Months? for you know, when I asked you where he was in April, then you ſaid he was at home; why do you doubt whether he was there in May or no? pray tell us why it is not as certain to you that he was not there in May as that he was there in June; why do you doubt more of it?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: I do not doubt but that he was there.

sp.speaker: Lord C. J.
sp.p: But why did you not anſwer then as readily to the one as to the other?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: My Lord, any one may miſtake.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This you were not prepared for, and it was a queſtion you did not come ready to anſwer: are you a Roman-Catholick?

sp.speaker: Poole.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord. (Here the people laugh'd.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: Look you, you muſt know there is no other uſe to be made of it, but onely to ſhew, that Proteſtants are ſo averſe to Popery in England, that they will not endure a Roman-Catholick in England. But they are good Evidence, and competent Witneſſes, I muſt tell you that, and no man muſt deny it: for though you deny Heaven to us, yet we will not deny Heaven to you, nor Witneſſes; though you ſay Heriticks will be damn'd, yet we hope they will never, while they do not follow your practiſes. (At which the people gave a great ſhout.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt pardon the peoples ſhouting; for you have turned their hearts ſo, that there is no living for a Papiſt in England, I will maintain it. (And then the people ſhouted again.) You ſhall have all the Iuſtice that can be, and all the favour the Law will allow.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: If there be but a place for us in Heaven, I am contented. My Lord, I deſire you will be pleaſed to ask this Mrs. K •• th, Winford, whether ſhe does not remember that I came from my Lord Aſton's the Monday before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mrs. Winford, what ſay you? do you remember any paſſages about the time he left your houſe?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p:
My Lord, I did not know directly and poſitively what I ſhould come to anſwer,
and therefore I cannot recollect my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know that he went to any Gentlemans houſe ſome time before he left your houſe?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he went often abroad.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To whoſe?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: To my Lord Aſtons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long before?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long did he ſtay at my Lord's? did he ever ſtay five or ſix days?

sp.speaker: Winford▪
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My meaning is this in plain Engliſh, to ask you plainly, and you ought in Conſcience to ſpeak the truth as much as if you were upon your Oath: for you are in the preſence of God, who will judge you as ſeverely for a falſhood in this Caſe, as in the other. I would ask you whether he could not poſſibly be abſent, and make a ſtep to London, and you be never the wiſer?

sp.speaker: Windford.
sp.p: My Lord, I am as confident as I can be of any thing in the world, of the contrary.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Might not he be in London the latter end of June or July, and you not know it, when he pretended to go to my Lord Aſton's?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: I do not know, but I am very confident he did not.

sp.speaker: L, C. J.
sp.p: But was he abſent long enough to have done it? can you charge your memory with that?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: It was poſſible it might be ſo, but I am confident it was not, becauſe I uſed to order my maid to get him his Linnen ready upon any Journey, & he had none now.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: My Lord, he took a Chamber to go into the Exerciſe; now, my Lord, he taking a Chamber on purpoſe for this very thing, he might pretend that, and come to London the while, and they not know it, becauſe he was ſhut up; for none are to come at them.

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: My Lord, I know not any ſuch thing of him; but this is a Rule amongſt them, that when they are ſo ſhut up, if there be a neceſſary occaſion to come to them about any particular buſineſs, as ſending them Linnen or ſo, they have admittance to them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you employ'd upon any ſuch extraordinary matter?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: My Lord, I uſed to go and ſee him, and carry him his Linnen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And can you charge your memory with that?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: Yes; my Lord I can.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When, the Latter end of July?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I often went to ſee him then, when he was gone from my houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he for all the former part of July till thoſe eight days?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: He was at my own houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When went he firſt into this recluſe way?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: He went from my houſe the 23th. of July.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he not cloſe when he was with you?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And the laſt eight dayes you had acceſs to him.

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: Yes, I had.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ask you, Are theſe people ſhut up at a certain time, and there is no coming to them upon any occaſion?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p:
My Lord, moſt of thoſe days I did ſee him, indeed he was ſhut up; but upon
any kind of buſineſs, as carrying of the Linnen, and ſometimes a pair of Gloves, and other things of his own, or ſometimes to ſpeak with him about buſineſs, were admitted to him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I ſee your Confinements are not ſo great as you would make them to be or he would have us think. I ask you once more, whether you can ſay that during the months of June and July, it was not poſſible for him to make a ſtep to London, and you never the wiſer?

sp.speaker: Winford
sp.p: I am very confident he did not; he was not abſent long enough to do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins.
sp.p: You ſaid juſt now, you could not ſay poſitively but he might be abſent for five or ſix days.

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: I do not believe he did: for he had no linnen with him, which he uſed to have, when he went to London.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But ſuppoſing he had no linnen, might he not go to London and you not know of it?

sp.speaker: Winford.
sp.p: I Can't tell whether he was abſent or no long enough to do it.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let me ſpeak; as I live, an innocent man will be loſt elſe. He ſays expreſly I was in Town in July; and gives this argument for it, That Mr. Aſhby was in Town, and he met me with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Oates was not ſo poſitive: he ſays it was either in June or July; but he rather thinks it was July. But Miſtris, might not he in the beginning of July be abſent ſo long as a man might go to London and return again, in the firſt three weeks of July, I mean?

sp.speaker: Winford▪
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot charge my memory, becauſe I did not know what I ſhould be asked, and ſo could not recollect my ſelf. I onely ſay I am confident of it, becauſe he always told me when he went ſuch a Journey, that I might make proviſion of Linnen to ſit him for it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Your reaſons are weak, becauſe he uſed to tell you that you might get him linnen: men upon extraordinary occaſions do extraordinary things; ſo that you are not to govern your ſelf by what he uſed to do in his acquainting you, or you in providing his linnen. This was no ordinary Errand, and therefore I don't ask you whether he had linnen from you or no; but you are onely to charge your ſelf with remembring whether he could not be abſent long enough out of your ſight to have been ſuch a Journey.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, give me fair play. He does charge it expreſly, and is preciſe to a day: He ſaith I was here in July after that Aſhby was come to Town, and before that he went out of Town: And he ſays that Aſhby came to Town in the middle of July, and went out of Town about the latter end of July or beginning of Auguſt ▪ Now, my Lord, I ſay this, he ſaying that Aſhby, came to Town the middle of July, and ſtaid there a fortnight, and then went to the Bath, & that I came to Town while that he was there; if I prove that I was in Staffordſhire from the 15th. or 16th of July to the end of the month, then I ſhall clear my ſelf evidently; for he does in effect charge me to be here ſome time in that fortnights time, and I prove that all the latter part of July I was in the country.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He does not charge it to a day, but he ſays it was about a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p:
Mr. Aſhby came to Town in the beginning or middle of July; I rather think it was the middle, but I dare not upon my Oath be poſitive as to the time; and in
that time Mr. Aſhby ſtaid in Town, mr. Gaven came to London: for I remember he ſaid he would go and ſee Father Aſhby, who was then at Wild-houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Prove where you were now all July. Call your Witneſes.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: I prove that I was at Wolverhampton from the 23th to the end of the month.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call your witneſſes to prove where you were the beginning, that can ſpeak expreſsly to it.

sp.speaker: Gaven:
sp.p: My Lord, I have them not here.

sp.speaker: L. C. J,
sp.p: Why then would you make us loſe all this time?

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: My Lord, I will tell you; hear the words of an ingenuous man being as I was innocent, not knowing What they intended to charge me with, I in my mind run over all that I could imagine I had at any time done that they could lay hold on. If I had been guilty of any thing, my own conſcience would have told me of it; and I ſhould have provided to have given ſome Anſwer to it: but being innocent, I was to ranſack my memory to ſum up all the paſſages of my life, where I had been, what I had ſaid, what I had done, that would give them any occaſion of accuſing me. And becauſe I did imagine they might think I was here the 24th of April, I brought witneſſes for that; and becauſe I did imagine that they might ſpeak of ſome Conſults in April, I ſent up for ſuch witneſſes at my own charge, as could teſtifie where I was then.

sp.speaker: L. C: J.
sp.p: But you have not one Proteſtant that teſtifies for you.

sp.speaker: Gavau,
sp.p: And now, my Lord I humbly caſt my ſelf upon the Honour and Juſtice of this Honourable and Juſt Court; to which I ſubmit my ſelf with all my heart and ſoul, haveing uſed all the remedies I can. I have cleared my ſelf as to the main day, the 24th of April, whereon all the pretended Plot lies: And I'le bring Witneſſes that ſhall ſwear I was not in London in Auguſt; and if my eternal Salvation lay upon it, I could averr I was not in London: and I wiſh I may be made an example of juſtice before all the world (in the ſight of God I ſpeak it) if I be not the moſt innocent perſon in the world, And, my Lord, ſeeing there is only his Oath for it, and my denial, I have onely one demand: I don't know whether it be not an extravagant one or no; if it be, I don't deſire to have it granted.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is that Demand?

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: You know that in the beginning of the Church (this learned and juſt Court muſt needs know that) that for one thouſand years together, it was a cuſtom, and grew to a conſtant law, for the Tryal of perſons accuſed of any capital Offence, where there was onely the accuſers Oath and the Accuſed's denial, for the priſoner to put himſelf upon the Tryal of Ordeal, to evidence his own Innocencie.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: We have no ſuch law now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
You are very fanciful, Mr. Gaven you believe that your cunning in asking ſuch a thing, will take much with the auditory; but this is onely an artificial Varniſh: You may do this with hopes of haveing it take with thoſe that are Roman Catholicks, who are ſo ſuperſtitious as to believe Innocency upon ſuch deſires; but we have a plain way of underſtanding here in England, and that helpt very much by the Proteſtant Religion: ſo that there is ſcarce any Artifice big enough to impoſe upon us. You ask a thing that ſounds much of a pretence to innocencie, and that it would be a mighty ſuffering if you ſhould miſcarry, becauſe you ask that you know you can't have. Our Eyes and our underſtandings are leſt us, though you do not leave their Underſtannings to your Proſelytes; but you are miſtaken, if you think to impoſe that upon us that you
do upon them: and you do ſo impoſe upon them. But i'll tell you, there is ſcarce any man with us that can be a Papiſt: for you cannot deceive and gull us, as you have done all that you have perverted to your way.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: Is it any harm, my Lord, to ask whether I might not be ſo tried?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, look you here, Mr. Gaven, the time is far ſpent; if you have any thing to ſay, we will hear you, if you have any witneſſes, call them, and we will examine them: but if not, the other Priſoners muſt be admitted to make their defence as well as you.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: All theſe ſix can prove that I was at Wolverhampton the laſt week in July.

p.hi: Then another Witneſs ſtood up for him.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: Where was I in July?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak to all July; but, my Lord I can declare, that Mr. Gaven was in Staffordſhire the laſt week of July every day, I am confident.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was the firſt three weeks in July?

sp.speaker: Witneſs,
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak as to that; but in the laſt week in July he came to an apartment of an houſe that I lived in.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Cook you, Mr. Gaven, you ſee what this Evidence is; ſhe ſays that you were in Staffordſhire the laſt week in July, for you had an apartment in the houſe ſhe lived in. Call another. (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was mr. Gaven in July laſt?

sp.speaker: 2 Witneſs,
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw him my ſelf at the latter end of July for very many days, for he was in a Room of the houſe that I lived in, I am ſure, moſt of the laſt week.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was he the laſt fortnight?

sp.speaker: 2 Witneſs,
sp.p: I am confident I ſaw him all the laſt fortnight, but I cannot be poſitive

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call another. (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was mr. Gaven in July?

sp.speaker: 3. Witneſs.
sp.p: My Lord, I lived in the ſame Town with him, and I do not remember that he was out all July, but the laſt week he was in our houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Well, call another. (Who ſtood up.)

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Where was Mr. Gaven in July laſt?

sp.speaker: 4 Witneſs,
sp.p: He was in July laſt, the laſt week, in a part of our houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: So then he came home from London the 23th or 24th of July. Well Mr. Gaven have you any more Witneſſes to any other purpoſe? for here are enough to this.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Whitebread, have you any Witneſſes to call?

sp.speaker: Wh,
sp.p: My Lord, I have only this, and I deſire to be heard in this point, to prove that Mr. Oats was miſtaken in his Evidence that he gave at the laſt Trial againſt Mr. Ireland.

sp.speaker: L C. J
sp.p: Look you, I muſt break in upon you; you have been told ſo often, all of you have been told it, and yet you are upon the former Trials again. You are now upon your trial for your life, if you could have diſproved any thing that he ſaid at a former trial, you ſhould have taken a legal way and convicted him of perjury; but now to charge him with a printed Paper is not fair. You muſt ſpeak to what he ſays now.

sp.speaker: Whitebread.
sp.p: He ſays the ſame now. But all that I ſay is this, If he be not honeſt, he can be witneſs in no caſe. I ſuppoſe if any one can prove him not Probus Teſtis, his Teſtimony is not to be received in any caſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p:
But how will you prove that? Come on, I'le teach you a little 〈…〉
• ill come to contradict a Witneſs, you ought to do it in a matter which
is the preſent debate here; for if you would convict him of any thing that he ſaid in Irelands Trial, we muſt try Irelands Cauſe over again. But if you will ſay any thing againſt what he ſays now, do.

sp.speaker: Whitebread,
sp.p: That which I would alledg is this, If he be convicted of perjury in one caſe, he is not to be believed in another.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: You ſay right, if he be convicted.

sp.speaker: Whitebread,
sp.p: He is not only then an incompetent Witneſs, for he cannot be ſaid to be probus teſtis, but he is improbus. Now this is that I can prove.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: Nay, you muſt ſhew it by a Record.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: You cannot have ſo little underſtanding, you that have been, and were to be ſo great a man among them, had been Provincial, and was to have been ſomewhat elſe. I have told you already, that to prove him to be a man that hath no faith in him he muſt be convicted. You muſt have indicted him, and convicted him, of the thing wherein he did commit perjury, and then he had been prepared to juſtifie himſelf. But ſhall you come now, and at this your Trial, and prove what he ſaid at Staleys Trial, and Colemans Trial, and Irelands Trial? And muſt we examine what matters have received a verdict and a judgment there? for conſider what will be the conſequence of it; if it ſhould be falſe, you there arraign a verdict. You ſhould have convicted him of the falſhood firſt.

sp.speaker: Whitebread,
sp.p: I deſire the Jury to take notice, that he does not ſtick to the Teſtimony that he gave then, for if he does it was falſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: They muſt not take notice of any thing that was done at a former Trial, unleſs it be ſpoken of now.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: Do not call any Witneſſes to prove what he ſaid then, but to diſprove what he hath ſaid now.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty hard matter to make a Prieſt underſtand one, for what I ſee. If the Witneſs ſhall not gain credit with the Jury that he came over with Sir Thomas Preſton, Sir John Warner; if they are ſatisfied by thoſe many Witneſſes, ten or twelve at leaſt, that it is falſe, they ought not to believe him; but as to that Teſtimony they ought to believe your Witneſſes, but he is not preſently guilty of perjury: for if they ſhould not give • redit to Mr. Oates, you muſt indict him, and another Jury muſt paſs upon him before he is convicted: for it is one thing to be forſworn and perjured, and another thing to be proved ſo; and he is not proved to be ſo, but by a Record for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Harcourt,
sp.p: If ſo be our Witneſſes cannot be lookt upon as good Witneſſes, then there can be no Commerce abroad in any other Country.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: They are no doubt good Witneſſes till they be proved otherwiſe, and they are left to the Jury to believe as they think fit.

sp.speaker: Harcourt,
sp.p: Now here are divers things that are brought againſt my ſelf by Mr. Bedlow, Mr. Prance, Mr Oates, and Mr Dugdale; if the Witneſſes that I bring, becauſe they are Roman Catholick, are not good Witneſſes, then I am in an hard caſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: Look then, you miſtake the thing; thoſe that are not Witneſſes, we do not hear at all; but our hearing them at all, proves that we look upon them as good Witneſſes. But when a man is a Witneſs, he is either of more credit, or of leſs credit, according to Circumſtances; and 'tis a proper queſtion to ask them, Whether they are Roman Catholicks: but they are Witneſſes without all queſtion.

sp.speaker: Harc
sp.p: I ſay, my Lord, theſe perſons are known to be every one of them very bad and flagitious perſons, and that every one of them have undertaken this courſe meerly to get a livelihood: they are men of deſperate fortunes, they get a living by ſwearing faſt, they find that the beſt trade.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: If you have any other Witneſſes, we will hear them. If you have have no other Witneſſes, then we muſt hear what the Kings Council reply, and then it will be your turn to ſay what you can in your defence.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: I have Witneſſes here. It is not indeed a poſitive Evidence, but a negative Evidence; and I have a Brother and a Siſter in Town, and upon my ſalvation I never came to Town but I came to their houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: That will ſignifie nothing. Mr. Harcourt, have you any more Witneſſes? if you have them, pray call them.

sp.speaker: Harcourt,
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to call them, if they be not to be believed becauſe they are Roman Catholicks.

sp.speaker: Sir Cr. Levins,
sp.p: 'Tis a miſtake; we do not refuſe any Witneſſes becauſe they are Roman Catholicks.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: No, we have not refuſed any one Point yet.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief J. North,
sp.p: If you have any more, pray call them, and don't ſpend the time.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſtice,
sp.p: Call a Prieſt or two if you will, we will hear them.

sp.speaker: Harcourt,
sp.p: Mr. Oates did accuſe me of paying fourſcore pounds at my chamber, and he did ſay afterwards it was at Wildhouſe, I have perſons to juſtifie what was done at my own chamber; and he ſays, Mr. Ireland was by; now here are Witneſſes to prove that Mr. Ireland was in Staffordſhire all the month of Auguſt, therefore he could not be preſent.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Does he ſay any ſuch thing now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: That was urged before; pray do not inſiſt upon that, it hath received a Trial.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: I'le tell you what he ſays, and I'le ask him the queſtion: Dr. Oates, it is ſuppoſed by your teſtimony that Mr. Ireland and Mr. Harcourt were together when this fourſcore pounds was paid for the Villains that went to Windſor to murder the King?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I never ſaid ſuch a word.

sp.speaker: Harcourt,
sp.p: Here it is in the Trial.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: I ſtand not by the Printed 〈…〉 is no Record in Law. In ſhort, Were Mr. Ireland and Mr. Harcourt together 〈◊〉 time?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No they were not.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: He did then ſay, that he did receive of Mr. Ireland, the 2d of September, 20 s. that he borrowed of him: now the 2d of September he was at Boſcobel.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I was not poſitive as to the day; but as near as I remember (thoſe were the words I ſaid) it was the ſecond of September; but whether it was the firſt, ſecond, ſeventh, eighth, or ninth, I would not be poſitive in it.

div.p: Then the Priſoners called Pendrel and his Wife, and Gifford and his Wife; and Gifford ſtood up.

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p:
My Lord, I was here the laſt Seſſions, where I did teſtifie the ſeeing of Mr. Ireland in Staffordſhire on the 24th of Auguſt, Bartholomew-day, and the next day after; at which time Mr. Oates ſaid that he ſaw him here in Town. But Mr. Oates could not be particular in every thing; but at laſt he came to a circumſtance, and averred that
the firſt or ſecond of September he did receive Twenty ſhillings of Mr. Ireland in Harcourts Chamber; he ſaid it was about the Faſt day.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: That was as near as I remembred.

sp.speaker: Gifford,
sp.p: Here is in Court at leaſt ſix people that know it; I ſaw him ſeveral other of thoſe days there; but theſe ſix people converted with him every day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: How do you know al that?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: Come, come, you muſt not ſpeak as to what he ſaid in Irelands Trial.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What time was it that Mr. Harcourt and Mr. Ireland conferred together about this ſame buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I do not charge Ireland, but I charge Harcourt with being at Wildhouſe, and that there Coleman met him, and that there was the greateſt part of the money, which was carried back to Harcourts Chamber, and given to the perſon that was to carry it down to Windſor; but Mr. Coleman was gone away before, and had leſt a Guiney behind him which was given to the meſſenger for expedition.

sp.speaker: Lord. Chief Juſt.
sp.p: I am miſtaken if you have not teſtified that Ireland was in Town in Auguſt and September with Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Ireland took his leave of London betwixt the 8th and the 12th of Auguſt, as to go to St. Omers.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Here is the matter, they muſt have right, though there be never ſo much time loſt, and patience ſpent. Say they, We muſt prove and contradict men by ſuch matters as we can; people may ſwear downright things, and 'tis impoſſible to contradict them; but we will call Witneſſes to prove thoſe particulars that can be proved: • ay where Mr. Ireland was in Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr Oates,
sp.p: He took his leave of us in Town in Auguſt, and that was between the eighth and twelfth at Harcourts Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What do you infer from Irelands being there then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I'le tell you what I deſign in it: your Lordſhip may perceive that I did methodize my Evidence according to the time; for I ſaid this was our buſineſs in April, this in July; and now we come to the buſineſs of Auguſt, ſaid I, we took our leaves of Mr. Ireland between the eighth and twelfth. I ſaid in July Mr. Fenwick was out of Town, but then if your Lordſhip remembers I ſaid he was in Town, and took his leave of Mr. Ireland between the eighth and the twelfth of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Was Mr▪ Ireland in Fenwicks company at that time in Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he was when he took his leave.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did they talk then of this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: They took their leaves of one another, but as to what particular things of the Plot they ſpoke about, I don't remember.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Look you now, mind what he ſays, Ireland and Fenwick were together in Auguſt between the eighth and the twelfth, but being asked, Whether they were met on purpoſe to talk of the Plot? he ſays he does not remember the particulars.

div.p: Here the Lady Southcott, her Son, and her Daughter were called.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſay that Fenwick there at the Bar had converſe with Ireland in Auguſt for the carrying on of the Plot?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: My rule is this in doubtful caſes, when men are upon their lives, I had rather hear what is impertinent, than not let them make a full defence.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt. North,
sp.p: I had rather hear things at a venture, than forbid things at a venture.

div.p: Lady Southcott ſtood up.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: How long were you in Mr. Irelands Company?

sp.speaker: Lady Southcott,
sp.p: From the fifth of Auguſt to the ſixteenth.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: What every day?

sp.speaker: Lady Southcott,
sp.p: Yes, every day.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, here is Sarah Pain who before hath teſtified what ſhe hath known in this matter. If your Lordſhip pleaſe I deſire ſhe may be call'd in readineſs to ſpeak to it.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: Are you ſure it was the fifth?

sp.speaker: Lady Southcott,
sp.p: Yes, as ſure as I can be of any thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: Dr. Oates, you had beſt keep your Evidence intire till the laſt.

div.p: Then Sir John Southcott was called, and appeared.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you know mr. Ireland?

sp.speaker: Sir John Southcott,
sp.p: Yes, I did know him by face.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Where did you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Sir John Southcott
sp.p: I ſaw him the fifth of Auguſt at St. Albans.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch Juſt.
sp.p: And did he travel along with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo. Southcot,
sp.p: Yes, he did travel along with us the ſixth, ſeventh, eighth and ninth.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How many days did he travel along with you?

sp.speaker: Sir John Southcott,
sp.p: He trave'ld along with us four days together I am ſure.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What from the 5th to the 9th?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn Southcott.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is this all that you can ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn Southcott.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But we would know where he was afterwards; did you ſee him after the 9th?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn Southcott,
sp.p: My Lord, I ſaw him at St Albans, and we went from thence to Northampton, and from thence to Coventry, and from thence to my Lord Aſtons, that is four days; and I ſaw him Thurſday, I ſaw him Friday, Saturday, and Munday following. Tueſday I had occaſion to go further into the Country, and he went along with us; ſo I ſaw him Tueſday, Wedneſday, Thurſday and Friday, afterwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why then you ſaw him at leaſt twelve days?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn Southcott,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any more?

div.p: Then Mr. Edward Southcott ſtood up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you here when Ireland was tryed?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn Southcott,
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Ireland in Auguſt laſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Southcott,
sp.p: The third of Auguſt he came down to my Lord Aſtons at Stanmore, they ſaid ſo; but I cannot ſwear he came that night, but I ſaw him very early the next morning; the 5th we went to St. Alban, & we kept on till we came to Tixall; and I was in his company from the 4th to the 16th.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why, you hear what he ſays, he was in company with him every day from the 4th to the 16th.

sp.speaker: Gaven,
sp.p: Call Mrs. Harewell and her Daughter, Mrs. Gifford, and Mrs. Pendrell.

div.p: Then Mrs. Harewell ſtood up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee Mr. Ireland in Auguſt laſt?

sp.speaker: Harewell.
sp.p: I ſaw Ireland in Auguſt laſt, the 17th day: He came then to my Houſe at Wolverhampton, and there he continued every day, and lay in my houſe every night till the 26th, day.

div.p: Then young Mrs. Harewell ſtood up.

sp.speaker: Harewell.
sp.p: Mr. Ireland came to our houſe in Staffordſhire the 17th of Auguſt, and ſtay'd there till the 26th; I ſaw him every day, unleſs it was Friday, the day before Bartholomew-day, when he went to Litchfield, and returned again.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: My Lord, there is a priſoner now in Newgate that can teſtifie the ſame.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North.
sp.p: Would you ask your fellow if you be a Thief? he is in for the ſame offence.

sp.speaker: Gaven.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know, if a man be not convicted of the ſame offence, whether he be not a good Witneſs?
